2310  def gen_code(self, parent):
2311  from psyclone.f2pygen import DirectiveGen
2312 
2313  # We're not doing nested parallelism so make sure that this
2314  # omp parallel do is not already within some parallel region
2315  self._not_within_omp_parallel_region()
2316 
2317  calls = self.reductions()
2318  zero_reduction_variables(calls, parent)
2319  private_str = self.list_to_string(self._get_private_list())
2320  parent.add(DirectiveGen(parent, "omp", "begin", "parallel do",
2321  "default(shared), private({0}), "
2322  "schedule({1})".
2323  format(private_str, self._omp_schedule) +
2324  self._reduction_string()))
2325  for child in self.children:
2326  child.gen_code(parent)
2327 
2328  # make sure the directive occurs straight after the loop body
2329  position = parent.previous_loop()
2330  parent.add(DirectiveGen(parent, "omp", "end", "parallel do", ""),
2331  position=["after", position])
2332 
2333  def update(self):
2334  '''
2335  Updates the fparser2 AST by inserting nodes for this OpenMP
2336  parallel do.
2337 
2338  :raises GenerationError: if the existing AST doesn't have the \
2339  correct structure to permit the insertion \
2340  of the OpenMP parallel do.
2341  '''
2342  from fparser.common.readfortran import FortranStringReader
2343  from fparser.two.Fortran2003 import Comment
2344  # Check that we haven't already been called
2345  if self._ast:
2346  return
2347  # Since this is an OpenMP (parallel) do, it can only be applied
2348  # to a single loop.
2349  if len(self._children) != 1:
2350  raise GenerationError(
2351  "An OpenMP PARALLEL DO can only be applied to a single loop "
2352  "but this Node has {0} children: {1}".
2353  format(len(self._children), self._children))
2354 
2355  # Find the locations in which we must insert the begin/end
2356  # directives...
2357  # Find the child of this node in the AST of our parent node
2358  # TODO make this robust by using the new 'children' method to
2359  # be introduced in fparser#105
2360  # We have to take care to find a parent node (in the fparser2 AST)
2361  # that has 'content'. This is because If-else-if blocks have their
2362  # 'content' as siblings of the If-then and else-if nodes.
2363  parent = self._parent._ast
2364  while parent:
2365  if hasattr(parent, "content"):
2366  break
2367  parent = parent._parent
2368  if not parent:
2369  raise InternalError("Failed to find parent node in which to "
2370  "insert OpenMP parallel do directive")
2371  start_idx = parent.content.index(self._children[0]._ast)
2372 
2373  # Create the start directive
2374  text = ("!$omp parallel do default(shared), private({0}), "
2375  "schedule({1})".format(",".join(self._get_private_list()),
2376  self._omp_schedule))
2377  startdir = Comment(FortranStringReader(text,
2378  ignore_comments=False))
2379 
2380  # Create the end directive and insert it after the node in
2381  # the AST representing our last child
2382  enddir = Comment(FortranStringReader("!$omp end parallel do",
2383  ignore_comments=False))
2384  if start_idx == len(parent.content) - 1:
2385  parent.content.append(enddir)
2386  else:
2387  parent.content.insert(start_idx+1, enddir)
2388 
2389  # Insert the start directive (do this second so we don't have
2390  # to correct the location)
2391  self._ast = startdir
2392  parent.content.insert(start_idx, self._ast)

2530 
2531  def check_vector_halos_differ(self, node):
2532  '''helper method which checks that two halo exchange nodes (one being
2533  self and the other being passed by argument) operating on the
2534  same field, both have vector fields of the same size and use
2535  different vector indices. If this is the case then the halo
2536  exchange nodes do not depend on each other. If this is not the
2537  case then an internal error will have occured and we raise an
2538  appropriate exception.
2539 
2540  :param node: a halo exchange which should exchange the same
2541  field as self
2542  :type node: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.HaloExchange`
2543  :raises GenerationError: if the argument passed is not a halo exchange
2544  :raises GenerationError: if the field name in the halo
2545  exchange passed in has a different name to the field in this
2546  halo exchange
2547  :raises GenerationError: if the field in this halo exchange is
2548  not a vector field
2549  :raises GenerationError: if the vector size of the field in
2550  this halo exchange is different to vector size of the field in
2551  the halo exchange passed by argument.
2552  :raises GenerationError: if the vector index of the field in
2553  this halo exchange is the same as the vector index of the
2554  field in the halo exchange passed by argument.
2555 
2556  '''
2557 
2558  if not isinstance(node, HaloExchange):
2559  raise GenerationError(
2560  "Internal error, the argument passed to "
2561  "HaloExchange.check_vector_halos_differ() is not "
2562  "a halo exchange object")
2563 
2564  if self.field.name != node.field.name:
2565  raise GenerationError(
2566  "Internal error, the halo exchange object passed to "
2567  "HaloExchange.check_vector_halos_differ() has a different "
2568  "field name '{0}' to self "
2569  "'{1}'".format(node.field.name, self.field.name))
2570 
2571  if self.field.vector_size <= 1:
2572  raise GenerationError(
2573  "Internal error, HaloExchange.check_vector_halos_differ() "
2574  "a halo exchange depends on another halo "
2575  "exchange but the vector size of field '{0}' is 1".
2576  format(self.field.name))
2577 
2578  if self.field.vector_size != node.field.vector_size:
2579  raise GenerationError(
2580  "Internal error, HaloExchange.check_vector_halos_differ() "
2581  "a halo exchange depends on another halo "
2582  "exchange but the vector sizes for field '{0}' differ".
2583  format(self.field.name))
2584 
2585  if self.vector_index == \
2586  node.vector_index:
2587  raise GenerationError(
2588  "Internal error, HaloExchange.check_vector_halos_differ() "
2589  "a halo exchange depends on another halo "
2590  "exchange but both vector id's ('{0}') of field '{1}' are "
2591  "the same".format(self.vector_index, self.field.name))
2592 
2593  def view(self, indent=0):
2594  '''
2595  Write out a textual summary of the OpenMP Parallel Do Directive
2596  and then call the view() method of any children.
2597 
2598  :param indent: Depth of indent for output text
2599  :type indent: integer
2600  '''
2601  print(self.indent(indent) + (
2602  "{0}[field='{1}', type='{2}', depth={3}, "
2603  "check_dirty={4}]".format(self.coloured_text, self._field.name,
2604  self._halo_type,
2605  self._halo_depth, self._check_dirty)))

2817  def has_inc_arg(self, mapping={}):
2818  ''' Returns True if any of the Kernels called within this
2819  loop have an argument with INC access. Returns False otherwise '''
2820  assert mapping != {}, "psyGen:Loop:has_inc_arg: Error - a mapping "\
2821  "must be provided"
2822  for kern_call in self.kern_calls():
2823  for arg in kern_call.arguments.args:
2824  if arg.access.lower() == mapping["inc"]:
2825  return True
2826  return False
2827 
2828  def unique_modified_args(self, mapping, arg_type):
2829  '''Return all unique arguments of type arg_type from Kernels in this
2830  loop that are modified'''
2831  arg_names = []
2832  args = []
2833  for call in self.calls():
2834  for arg in call.arguments.args:
2835  if arg.type.lower() == arg_type:
2836  if arg.access.lower() != mapping["read"]:
2837  if arg.name not in arg_names:
2838  arg_names.append(arg.name)
2839  args.append(arg)
2840  return args
2841 
2842  def args_filter(self, arg_types=None, arg_accesses=None, unique=False):
2843  '''Return all arguments of type arg_types and arg_accesses. If these
2844  are not set then return all arguments. If unique is set to
2845  True then only return uniquely named arguments'''
2846  all_args = []
2847  all_arg_names = []
2848  for call in self.calls():
2849  call_args = args_filter(call.arguments.args, arg_types,
2850  arg_accesses)
2851  if unique:
2852  for arg in call_args:
2853  if arg.name not in all_arg_names:
2854  all_args.append(arg)
2855  all_arg_names.append(arg.name)
2856  else:
2857  all_args.extend(call_args)
2858  return all_args
2859 
2860  def gen_code(self, parent):
2861  '''
2862  Generate the Fortran Loop and any associated code.
2863 
2864  :param parent: the node in the f2pygen AST to which to add content.
2865  :type parent: :py:class:`psyclone.f2pygen.SubroutineGen`
2866 
2867  '''
2868  if not self.is_openmp_parallel():
2869  calls = self.reductions()
2870  zero_reduction_variables(calls, parent)
2871 
2872  if self.root.opencl or (self._start == "1" and self._stop == "1"):
2873  # no need for a loop
2874  for child in self.children:
2875  child.gen_code(parent)
2876  else:
2877  from psyclone.f2pygen import DoGen, DeclGen
2878  do = DoGen(parent, self._variable_name, self._start, self._stop)
2879  # need to add do loop before children as children may want to add
2880  # info outside of do loop
2881  parent.add(do)
2882  for child in self.children:
2883  child.gen_code(do)
2884  my_decl = DeclGen(parent, datatype="integer",
2885  entity_decls=[self._variable_name])
2886  parent.add(my_decl)

2889 class Call(Node):
2890  '''
2891  Represents a call to a sub-program unit from within the PSy layer.
2892 
2893  :param parent: parent of this node in the PSyIR.
2894  :type parent: sub-class of :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Node`
2895  :param call: information on the call itself, as obtained by parsing \
2896  the Algorithm layer code.
2897  :type call: :py:class:`psyclone.parse.KernelCall`
2898  :param str name: the name of the routine being called.
2899  :param arguments: object holding information on the kernel arguments, \
2900  as extracted from kernel meta-data.
2901  :type arguments: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Arguments`
2902 
2903  :raises GenerationError: if any of the arguments to the call are \
2904  duplicated.
2905  '''
2906  def __init__(self, parent, call, name, arguments):
2907  Node.__init__(self, children=[], parent=parent)
2908  self._arguments = arguments
2909  self._name = name
2910  self._iterates_over = call.ktype.iterates_over
2911 
2912  # check algorithm arguments are unique for a kernel or
2913  # built-in call
2914  arg_names = []
2915  for arg in self._arguments.args:
2916  if arg.text:
2917  text = arg.text.lower().replace(" ", "")
2918  if text in arg_names:
2919  raise GenerationError(
2920  "Argument '{0}' is passed into kernel '{1}' code more "
2921  "than once from the algorithm layer. This is not "
2922  "allowed.".format(arg.text, self._name))
2923  else:
2924  arg_names.append(text)
2925 
2926  # visual properties
2927  self._width = 250
2928  self._height = 30
2929  self._shape = None
2930  self._text = None
2931  self._canvas = None
2932  self._arg_descriptors = None
2933 
2934  # initialise any reduction information
2935  args = args_filter(arguments.args,
2936  arg_types=MAPPING_SCALARS.values(),
2937  arg_accesses=MAPPING_REDUCTIONS.values())
2938  if args:
2939  self._reduction = True
2940  if len(args) != 1:
2941  raise GenerationError(
2942  "PSyclone currently only supports a single reduction "
2943  "in a kernel or builtin")
2944  self._reduction_arg = args[0]
2945  else:
2946  self._reduction = False
2947  self._reduction_arg = None
2948

2950  def args(self):
2951  '''Return the list of arguments associated with this node. Overide the
2952  base method and simply return our arguments. '''
2953  return self.arguments.args

2958  and then call the view() method of any children.
2959 
2960  :param indent: Depth of indent for output text
2961  :type indent: integer
2962  '''
2963  print(self.indent(indent) + self.coloured_text,
2964  self.name + "(" + self.arguments.names + ")")
2965  for entity in self._children:
2966  entity.view(indent=indent + 1)

3014  @property

3016  '''Determine whether this kernel/builtin is enclosed within an OpenMP
3017  do loop. If so report whether it has the reproducible flag
3018  set. Note, this also catches OMPParallelDo Directives but they
3019  have reprod set to False so it is OK.'''

3026  @property
3027  def local_reduction_name(self):
3028  '''Generate a local variable name that is unique for the current
3029  reduction argument name. This is used for thread-local
3030  reductions with reproducible reductions '''
3031  var_name = self._reduction_arg.name

3037  def zero_reduction_variable(self, parent, position=None):
3038  '''
3039  Generate code to zero the reduction variable and to zero the local
3040  reduction variable if one exists. The latter is used for reproducible
3041  reductions, if specified.
3042 
3043  :param parent: the Node in the AST to which to add new code.
3044  :type parent: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Node`
3045  :param str position: where to position the new code in the AST.
3046  :raises GenerationError: if the variable to zero is not of type \
3047  gh_real or gh_integer.
3048  :raises GenerationError: if the reprod_pad_size (read from the \
3049  configuration file) is less than 1.
3050 
3051  '''
3052  from psyclone.f2pygen import AssignGen, DeclGen, AllocateGen
3053  if not position:
3054  position = ["auto"]
3055  var_name = self._reduction_arg.name
3056  local_var_name = self.local_reduction_name
3057  var_type = self._reduction_arg.type
3058  if var_type == "gh_real":
3059  zero = "0.0_r_def"
3060  kind_type = "r_def"
3061  data_type = "real"
3062  elif var_type == "gh_integer":
3063  zero = "0"
3064  kind_type = None
3065  data_type = "integer"
3066  else:
3067  raise GenerationError(
3068  "zero_reduction variable should be one of ['gh_real', "
3069  "'gh_integer'] but found '{0}'".format(var_type))
3070 
3071  parent.add(AssignGen(parent, lhs=var_name, rhs=zero),
3072  position=position)
3073  if self.reprod_reduction:
3074  parent.add(DeclGen(parent, datatype=data_type,
3075  entity_decls=[local_var_name],
3076  allocatable=True, kind=kind_type,
3077  dimension=":,:"))
3078  nthreads = self._name_space_manager.create_name(
3079  root_name="nthreads", context="PSyVars", label="nthreads")
3080  if Config.get().reprod_pad_size < 1:
3081  raise GenerationError(
3082  "REPROD_PAD_SIZE in {0} should be a positive "
3083  "integer, but it is set to '{1}'.".format(
3084  Config.get().filename, Config.get().reprod_pad_size))
3085  pad_size = str(Config.get().reprod_pad_size)
3086  parent.add(AllocateGen(parent, local_var_name + "(" + pad_size +
3087  "," + nthreads + ")"), position=position)
3088  parent.add(AssignGen(parent, lhs=local_var_name,
3089  rhs=zero), position=position)
3090 
3091  def reduction_sum_loop(self, parent):
3092  '''generate the appropriate code to place after the end parallel
3093  region'''
3094  from psyclone.f2pygen import DoGen, AssignGen, DeallocateGen
3095  # TODO we should initialise self._name_space_manager in the
3096  # constructor!
3097  self._name_space_manager = NameSpaceFactory().create()
3098  thread_idx = self._name_space_manager.create_name(
3099  root_name="th_idx", context="PSyVars", label="thread_index")
3100  nthreads = self._name_space_manager.create_name(
3101  root_name="nthreads", context="PSyVars", label="nthreads")
3102  var_name = self._reduction_arg.name
3103  local_var_name = self.local_reduction_name
3104  local_var_ref = self._reduction_ref(var_name)
3105  reduction_access = self._reduction_arg.access
3106  try:
3107  reduction_operator = REDUCTION_OPERATOR_MAPPING[reduction_access]
3108  except KeyError:
3109  raise GenerationError(
3110  "unsupported reduction access '{0}' found in DynBuiltin:"
3111  "reduction_sum_loop(). Expected one of '{1}'".
3112  format(reduction_access,
3113  list(REDUCTION_OPERATOR_MAPPING.keys())))
3114  do_loop = DoGen(parent, thread_idx, "1", nthreads)
3115  do_loop.add(AssignGen(do_loop, lhs=var_name, rhs=var_name +
3116  reduction_operator + local_var_ref))
3117  parent.add(do_loop)
3118  parent.add(DeallocateGen(parent, local_var_name))
3119 
3120  def _reduction_ref(self, name):
3121  '''Return the name unchanged if OpenMP is set to be unreproducible, as
3122  we will be using the OpenMP reduction clause. Otherwise we
3123  will be computing the reduction ourselves and therefore need
3124  to store values into a (padded) array separately for each
3125  thread.'''
3126  if self.reprod_reduction:
3127  idx_name = self._name_space_manager.create_name(
3128  root_name="th_idx",
3129  context="PSyVars",
3130  label="thread_index")
3131  local_name = self._name_space_manager.create_name(
3132  root_name="l_"+name,
3133  context="PSyVars",
3134  label=name)
3135  return local_name + "(1," + idx_name + ")"
3136  else:
3137  return name

3182 class Kern(Call):
3183  '''
3184  Class representing a Kernel call within the Schedule (AST) of an Invoke.
3185 
3186  :param type KernelArguments: the API-specific sub-class of \
3187  :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Arguments` to \
3188  create.
3189  :param call: Details of the call to this kernel in the Algorithm layer.
3190  :type call: :py:class:`psyclone.parse.KernelCall`.
3191  :param parent: the parent of this Node (kernel call) in the Schedule.
3192  :type parent: sub-class of :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Node`.
3193  :param bool check: Whether or not to check that the number of arguments \
3194  specified in the kernel meta-data matches the number \
3195  provided by the call in the Algorithm layer.
3196  :raises GenerationError: if(check) and the number of arguments in the \
3197  call does not match that in the meta-data.
3198  '''
3199  def __init__(self, KernelArguments, call, parent=None, check=True):
3200  Call.__init__(self, parent, call, call.ktype.procedure.name,
3201  KernelArguments(call, self))
3202  self._module_name = call.module_name
3203  self._module_code = call.ktype._ast
3204  self._kernel_code = call.ktype.procedure
3205  self._fp2_ast = None # The fparser2 AST for the kernel
3206  # Whether or not this kernel has been transformed
3207  self._modified = False
3208  # Whether or not to in-line this kernel into the module containing
3209  # the PSy layer
3210  self._module_inline = False
3211  if check and len(call.ktype.arg_descriptors) != len(call.args):
3212  raise GenerationError(
3213  "error: In kernel '{0}' the number of arguments specified "
3214  "in the kernel metadata '{1}', must equal the number of "
3215  "arguments in the algorithm layer. However, I found '{2}'".
3216  format(call.ktype.procedure.name,
3217  len(call.ktype.arg_descriptors),
3218  len(call.args)))
3219  self.arg_descriptors = call.ktype.arg_descriptors
3220 
3221  def __str__(self):
3222  return "kern call: "+self._name
3223

3226  '''
3227  :return: The name of the Fortran module that contains this kernel
3228  :rtype: string
3229  '''
3230  return self._module_name

3234  ''' Return the name to use in a dag for this node'''

3237  @property

3241  @module_inline.setter
3242  def module_inline(self, value):
3243  '''
3244  Setter for whether or not to module-inline this kernel.
3245 
3246  :param bool value: Whether or not to module-inline this kernel.
3247  :raises NotImplementedError: if module-inlining is enabled and the \
3248  kernel has been transformed.
3249  '''
3250  # check all kernels in the same invoke as this one and set any
3251  # with the same name to the same value as this one. This is
3252  # required as inlining (or not) affects all calls to the same
3253  # kernel within an invoke. Note, this will set this kernel as
3254  # well so there is no need to set it locally.
3255  if value and self._fp2_ast:
3256  # TODO #229. We take the existence of an fparser2 AST for
3257  # this kernel to mean that it has been transformed. Since
3258  # kernel in-lining is currently implemented via
3259  # manipulation of the fparser1 AST, there is at present no
3260  # way to inline such a kernel.
3261  raise NotImplementedError(
3262  "Cannot module-inline a transformed kernel ({0}).".
3263  format(self.name))
3264  my_schedule = self.ancestor(Schedule)
3265  for kernel in self.walk(my_schedule.children, Kern):
3266  if kernel.name == self.name:
3267  kernel._module_inline = value

3269  def view(self, indent=0):
3270  '''
3271  Write out a textual summary of this Kernel-call node to stdout
3272  and then call the view() method of any children.
3273 
3274  :param indent: Depth of indent for output text
3275  :type indent: integer
3276  '''
3277  print(self.indent(indent) + self.coloured_text,
3278  self.name + "(" + self.arguments.names + ")",
3279  "[module_inline=" + str(self._module_inline) + "]")
3280  for entity in self._children:
3281  entity.view(indent=indent + 1)

3326  def incremented_arg(self, mapping={}):
3327  ''' Returns the argument that has INC access. Raises a
3328  FieldNotFoundError if none is found.

3331  with arguments with their metadata strings as keys

3347  def written_arg(self, mapping={}):

3349  Returns an argument that has WRITE or READWRITE access. Raises a

3354  metadata strings as keys

3364  for arg in self.arguments.args:

3366  return arg

3377  @property
3378  def ast(self):
3379  '''
3380  Generate and return the fparser2 AST of the kernel source.
3381 
3382  :returns: fparser2 AST of the Fortran file containing this kernel.
3383  :rtype: :py:class:`fparser.two.Fortran2003.Program`
3384  '''
3385  from fparser.common.readfortran import FortranStringReader
3386  from fparser.two import parser
3387  # If we've already got the AST then just return it
3388  if self._fp2_ast:
3389  return self._fp2_ast
3390  # Use the fparser1 AST to generate Fortran source
3391  fortran = self._module_code.tofortran()
3392  # Create an fparser2 Fortran2003 parser
3393  my_parser = parser.ParserFactory().create()
3394  # Parse that Fortran using our parser
3395  reader = FortranStringReader(fortran)
3396  self._fp2_ast = my_parser(reader)
3397  return self._fp2_ast
3398 
3399  @staticmethod
3400  def _new_name(original, tag, suffix):
3401  '''
3402  Construct a new name given the original, a tag and a suffix (which
3403  may or may not terminate the original name). If suffix is present
3404  in the original name then the `tag` is inserted before it.
3405 
3406  :param str original: The original name
3407  :param str tag: Tag to insert into new name
3408  :param str suffix: Suffix with which to end new name.
3409  :returns: New name made of original + tag + suffix
3410  :rtype: str
3411  '''
3412  if original.endswith(suffix):
3413  return original[:-len(suffix)] + tag + suffix
3414  return original + tag + suffix
3415 
3416  def rename_and_write(self):
3417  '''
3418  Writes the (transformed) AST of this kernel to file and resets the
3419  'modified' flag to False. By default (config.kernel_naming ==
3420  "multiple"), the kernel is re-named so as to be unique within
3421  the kernel output directory stored within the configuration
3422  object. Alternatively, if config.kernel_naming is "single"
3423  then no re-naming and output is performed if there is already
3424  a transformed copy of the kernel in the output dir. (In this
3425  case a check is performed that the transformed kernel already
3426  present is identical to the one that we would otherwise write
3427  to file. If this is not the case then we raise a GenerationError.)
3428 
3429  :raises GenerationError: if config.kernel_naming == "single" and a \
3430  different, transformed version of this \
3431  kernel is already in the output directory.
3432  :raises NotImplementedError: if the kernel has been transformed but \
3433  is also flagged for module-inlining.
3434 
3435  '''
3436  import os
3437  from psyclone.line_length import FortLineLength
3438 
3439  # If this kernel has not been transformed we do nothing
3440  if not self.modified:
3441  return
3442 
3443  # Remove any "_mod" if the file follows the PSyclone naming convention
3444  orig_mod_name = self.module_name[:]
3445  if orig_mod_name.endswith("_mod"):
3446  old_base_name = orig_mod_name[:-4]
3447  else:
3448  old_base_name = orig_mod_name[:]
3449 
3450  # We could create a hash of a string built from the name of the
3451  # Algorithm (module), the name/position of the Invoke and the
3452  # index of this kernel within that Invoke. However, that creates
3453  # a very long name so we simply ensure that kernel names are unique
3454  # within the user-supplied kernel-output directory.
3455  name_idx = -1
3456  fdesc = None
3457  while not fdesc:
3458  name_idx += 1
3459  new_suffix = "_{0}".format(name_idx)
3460  new_name = old_base_name + new_suffix + "_mod.f90"
3461  try:
3462  # Atomically attempt to open the new kernel file (in case
3463  # this is part of a parallel build)
3464  fdesc = os.open(
3465  os.path.join(Config.get().kernel_output_dir, new_name),
3466  os.O_CREAT | os.O_WRONLY | os.O_EXCL)
3467  except (OSError, IOError):
3468  # The os.O_CREATE and os.O_EXCL flags in combination mean
3469  # that open() raises an error if the file exists
3470  if Config.get().kernel_naming == "single":
3471  # If the kernel-renaming scheme is such that we only ever
3472  # create one copy of a transformed kernel then we're done
3473  break
3474  continue
3475 
3476  # Use the suffix we have determined to rename all relevant quantities
3477  # within the AST of the kernel code
3478  self._rename_ast(new_suffix)
3479 
3480  # Kernel is now self-consistent so unset the modified flag
3481  self.modified = False
3482 
3483  # If this kernel is being module in-lined then we do not need to
3484  # write it to file.
3485  if self.module_inline:
3486  # TODO #229. We cannot currently inline transformed kernels
3487  # (because that requires an fparser1 AST and we only have an
3488  # fparser2 AST of the modified kernel) so raise an error.
3489  raise NotImplementedError("Cannot module-inline a transformed "
3490  "kernel ({0})".format(self.name))
3491 
3492  # Generate the Fortran for this transformed kernel, ensuring that
3493  # we limit the line lengths
3494  fll = FortLineLength()
3495  new_kern_code = fll.process(str(self.ast))
3496 
3497  if not fdesc:
3498  # If we've not got a file descriptor at this point then that's
3499  # because the file already exists and the kernel-naming scheme
3500  # ("single") means we're not creating a new one.
3501  # Check that what we've got is the same as what's in the file
3502  with open(os.path.join(Config.get().kernel_output_dir,
3503  new_name), "r") as ffile:
3504  kern_code = ffile.read()
3505  if kern_code != new_kern_code:
3506  raise GenerationError(
3507  "A transformed version of this Kernel '{0}' already "
3508  "exists in the kernel-output directory ({1}) but is "
3509  "not the same as the current, transformed kernel and "
3510  "the kernel-renaming scheme is set to '{2}'. (If you "
3511  "wish to generate a new, unique kernel for every "
3512  "kernel that is transformed then use "
3513  "'--kernel-renaming multiple'.)".
3514  format(self._module_name+".f90",
3515  Config.get().kernel_output_dir,
3516  Config.get().kernel_naming))
3517  else:
3518  # Write the modified AST out to file
3519  os.write(fdesc, new_kern_code.encode())
3520  # Close the new kernel file
3521  os.close(fdesc)
3522 
3523  def _rename_ast(self, suffix):
3524  '''
3525  Renames all quantities (module, kernel routine, kernel derived type)
3526  in the kernel AST by inserting the supplied suffix. The resulting
3527  names follow the PSyclone naming convention (modules end with "_mod",
3528  types with "_type" and kernels with "_code").
3529 
3530  :param str suffix: the string to insert into the quantity names.
3531  '''
3532  from fparser.two.utils import walk_ast
3533  from fparser.two import Fortran2003
3534 
3535  # Use the suffix we have determined to create a new kernel name.
3536  # This will conform to the PSyclone convention of ending in "_code"
3537  orig_mod_name = self.module_name[:]
3538  orig_kern_name = self.name[:]
3539 
3540  new_kern_name = self._new_name(orig_kern_name, suffix, "_code")
3541  new_mod_name = self._new_name(orig_mod_name, suffix, "_mod")
3542 
3543  # Query the fparser2 AST to determine the name of the type that
3544  # contains the kernel subroutine as a type-bound procedure
3545  orig_type_name = ""
3546  new_type_name = ""
3547  dtypes = walk_ast(self.ast.content, [Fortran2003.Derived_Type_Def])
3548  for dtype in dtypes:
3549  tbound_proc = walk_ast(dtype.content,
3550  [Fortran2003.Type_Bound_Procedure_Part])
3551  names = walk_ast(tbound_proc[0].content, [Fortran2003.Name])
3552  if str(names[-1]) == self.name:
3553  # This is the derived type for this kernel. Now we need
3554  # its name...
3555  tnames = walk_ast(dtype.content, [Fortran2003.Type_Name])
3556  orig_type_name = str(tnames[0])
3557 
3558  # The new name for the type containing kernel metadata will
3559  # conform to the PSyclone convention of ending in "_type"
3560  new_type_name = self._new_name(orig_type_name, suffix, "_type")
3561  # Rename the derived type. We do this here rather than
3562  # search for Type_Name in the AST again below. We loop over
3563  # the list of type names so as to ensure we rename the type
3564  # in the end-type statement too.
3565  for name in tnames:
3566  if str(name) == orig_type_name:
3567  name.string = new_type_name
3568 
3569  # Change the name of this kernel and the associated module
3570  self.name = new_kern_name[:]
3571  self._module_name = new_mod_name[:]
3572 
3573  # Construct a dictionary for mapping from old kernel/type/module
3574  # names to the corresponding new ones
3575  rename_map = {orig_mod_name: new_mod_name,
3576  orig_kern_name: new_kern_name,
3577  orig_type_name: new_type_name}
3578 
3579  # Re-write the values in the AST
3580  names = walk_ast(self.ast.content, [Fortran2003.Name])
3581  for name in names:
3582  try:
3583  new_value = rename_map[str(name)]
3584  name.string = new_value[:]
3585  except KeyError:
3586  # This is not one of the names we are looking for
3587  continue
3588 
3589  @property
3590  def modified(self):
3591  '''
3592  :returns: Whether or not this kernel has been modified (transformed).
3593  :rtype: bool
3594  '''
3595  return self._modified
3596

3599  '''
3600  Setter for whether or not this kernel has been modified.

3604  self._modified = value

3722 
3723 class DataAccess(object):
3724  '''A helper class to simplify the determination of dependencies due to
3725  overlapping accesses to data associated with instances of the
3726  Argument class.
3727 
3728  '''
3729 
3730  def __init__(self, arg):
3731  '''Store the argument associated with the instance of this class and
3732  the Call, HaloExchange or GlobalSum (or a subclass thereof)
3733  instance with which the argument is associated.
3734 
3735  :param arg: the argument that we are concerned with. An \
3736  argument can be found in a `Call` a `HaloExchange` or a \
3737  `GlobalSum` (or a subclass thereof)
3738  :type arg: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Argument`
3739 
3740  '''
3741  # the `psyclone.psyGen.Argument` we are concerned with
3742  self._arg = arg
3743  # the call (Call, HaloExchange, or GlobalSum (or subclass)
3744  # instance to which the argument is associated
3745  self._call = arg.call
3746  # initialise _covered and _vector_index_access to keep pylint
3747  # happy
3748  self._covered = None
3749  self._vector_index_access = None
3750  # Now actually set them to the required initial values
3751  self.reset_coverage()
3752 
3753  def overlaps(self, arg):
3754  '''Determine whether the accesses to the provided argument overlap
3755  with the accesses of the source argument. Overlap means that
3756  the accesses share at least one memory location. For example,
3757  the arguments both access the 1st index of the same field.
3758 
3759  We do not currently deal with accesses to a subset of an
3760  argument (unless it is a vector). This distinction will need
3761  to be added once loop splitting is supported.
3762 
3763  :param arg: the argument to compare with our internal argument
3764  :type arg: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Argument`
3765  :return bool: True if there are overlapping accesses between \
3766  arguments (i.e. accesses share at least one memory \
3767  location) and False if not.
3768 
3769  '''
3770  if self._arg.name != arg.name:
3771  # the arguments are different args so do not overlap
3772  return False
3773 
3774  if isinstance(self._call, HaloExchange) and \
3775  isinstance(arg.call, HaloExchange) and \
3776  (self._arg.vector_size > 1 or arg.vector_size > 1):
3777  # This is a vector field and both accesses come from halo
3778  # exchanges. As halo exchanges only access a particular
3779  # vector, the accesses do not overlap if the vector indices
3780  # being accessed differ.
3781 
3782  # sanity check
3783  if self._arg.vector_size != arg.vector_size:
3784  raise InternalError(
3785  "DataAccess.overlaps(): vector sizes differ for field "
3786  "'{0}' in two halo exchange calls. Found '{1}' and "
3787  "'{2}'".format(arg.name, self._arg.vector_size,
3788  arg.vector_size))
3789  if self._call.vector_index != arg.call.vector_index:
3790  # accesses are to different vector indices so do not overlap
3791  return False
3792  # accesses do overlap
3793  return True
3794 
3795  def reset_coverage(self):
3796  '''Reset internal state to allow re-use of the object for a different
3797  situation.
3798 
3799  '''
3800  # False unless all data accessed by our local argument has
3801  # also been accessed by other arguments.
3802  self._covered = False
3803  # Used to store individual vector component accesses when
3804  # checking that all vector components have been accessed.
3805  self._vector_index_access = []
3806 
3807  def update_coverage(self, arg):
3808  '''Record any overlap between accesses to the supplied argument and
3809  the internal argument. Overlap means that the accesses to the
3810  two arguments share at least one memory location. If the
3811  overlap results in all of the accesses to the internal
3812  argument being covered (either directly or as a combination
3813  with previous arguments) then ensure that the covered() method
3814  returns True. Covered means that all memory accesses by the
3815  internal argument have at least one corresponding access by
3816  the supplied arguments.
3817 
3818  :param arg: the argument used to compare with our internal \
3819  argument in order to update coverage information
3820  :type arg: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Argument`
3821 
3822  '''
3823 
3824  if not self.overlaps(arg):
3825  # There is no overlap so there is nothing to update.
3826  return
3827 
3828  if isinstance(arg.call, HaloExchange) and \
3829  self._arg.vector_size > 1:
3830  # The supplied argument is a vector field coming from a
3831  # halo exchange and therefore only accesses one of the
3832  # vectors
3833 
3834  if isinstance(self._call, HaloExchange):
3835  # I am also a halo exchange so only access one of the
3836  # vectors. At this point the vector indices of the two
3837  # halo exchange fields must be the same, which should
3838  # never happen due to checks in the `overlaps()`
3839  # method earlier
3840  raise InternalError(
3841  "DataAccess:update_coverage() The halo exchange vector "
3842  "indices for '{0}' are the same. This should never "
3843  "happen".format(self._arg.name))
3844  else:
3845  # I am not a halo exchange so access all components of
3846  # the vector. However, the supplied argument is a halo
3847  # exchange so only accesses one of the
3848  # components. This results in partial coverage
3849  # (i.e. the overlap in accesses is partial). Therefore
3850  # record the index that is accessed and check whether
3851  # all indices are now covered (which would mean `full`
3852  # coverage).
3853  if arg.call.vector_index in self._vector_index_access:
3854  raise InternalError(
3855  "DataAccess:update_coverage() Found more than one "
3856  "dependent halo exchange with the same vector index")
3857  self._vector_index_access.append(arg.call.vector_index)
3858  if len(self._vector_index_access) != self._arg.vector_size:
3859  return
3860  # This argument is covered i.e. all accesses by the
3861  # internal argument have a corresponding access in one of the
3862  # supplied arguments.
3863  self._covered = True
3864 
3865  @property
3866  def covered(self):
3867  '''Returns true if all of the data associated with this argument has
3868  been covered by the arguments provided in update_coverage
3869 
3870  :return bool: True if all of an argument is covered by \
3871  previous accesses and False if not.
3872 
3873  '''
3874  return self._covered
3875 
3876 
3877 class Argument(object):
3878  ''' Argument base class '''
3879 
3880  def __init__(self, call, arg_info, access):
3881  '''
3882  :param call: the call that this argument is associated with
3883  :type call: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Call`
3884  :param arg_info: Information about this argument collected by
3885  the parser
3886  :type arg_info: :py:class:`psyclone.parse.Arg`
3887  :param access: the way in which this argument is accessed in
3888  the 'Call'. Valid values are specified in 'MAPPING_ACCESSES'
3889  (and may be modified by the particular API).
3890  :type access: str
3891 
3892  '''
3893  self._call = call
3894  self._text = arg_info.text
3895  self._orig_name = arg_info.varName
3896  self._form = arg_info.form
3897  self._is_literal = arg_info.is_literal()
3898  self._access = access
3899  self._name_space_manager = NameSpaceFactory().create()
3900 
3901  if self._orig_name is None:
3902  # this is an infrastructure call literal argument. Therefore
3903  # we do not want an argument (_text=None) but we do want to
3904  # keep the value (_name)
3905  self._name = arg_info.text
3906  self._text = None
3907  else:
3908  # Use our namespace manager to create a unique name unless
3909  # the context and label match in which case return the
3910  # previous name.
3911  self._name = self._name_space_manager.create_name(
3912  root_name=self._orig_name, context="AlgArgs", label=self._text)
3913  # _writers and _readers need to be instances of this class,
3914  # rather than static variables, as the mapping that is used
3915  # depends on the API and this is only known when a subclass of
3916  # Argument is created (as the local MAPPING_ACCESSES will be
3917  # used). For example, a dynamo0p3 api instantiation of a
3918  # DynArgument (subclass of Argument) will use the
3919  # MAPPING_ACCESSES specified in the dynamo0p3 file which
3920  # overide the default ones in this file.
3921  self._write_access_types = [MAPPING_ACCESSES["write"],
3922  MAPPING_ACCESSES["readwrite"],
3923  MAPPING_ACCESSES["inc"],
3924  MAPPING_REDUCTIONS["sum"]]
3925  self._read_access_types = [MAPPING_ACCESSES["read"],
3926  MAPPING_ACCESSES["readwrite"],
3927  MAPPING_ACCESSES["inc"]]
3928  self._vector_size = 1
3929 
3930  def __str__(self):
3931  return self._name
3932 
3933  @property
3934  def name(self):
3935  return self._name
3936 
3937  @property
3938  def text(self):
3939  return self._text
3940 
3941  @property
3942  def form(self):
3943  return self._form
3944 
3945  @property
3946  def is_literal(self):
3947  return self._is_literal
3948

3951  return self._access
3952

3954  def access(self, value):
3955  ''' set the access type for this argument '''
3956  self._access = value
3957

3960  '''Return the type of the argument. API's that do not have this
3961  concept (such as gocean0.1 and dynamo0.1) can use this
3962  baseclass version which just returns "field" in all
3963  cases. API's with this concept can override this method '''
3964  return "field"

3976  def set_kernel_arg(self, parent, index, kname):
3977  '''
3978  Generate the code to set this argument for an OpenCL kernel.
3979 
3980  :param parent: the node in the Schedule to which to add the code.
3981  :type parent: :py:class:`psyclone.f2pygen.SubroutineGen`
3982  :param int index: the (zero-based) index of this argument in the \
3983  list of kernel arguments.
3984  :param str kname: the name of the OpenCL kernel.
3985  '''
3986  from psyclone.f2pygen import AssignGen, CallGen
3987  # Look up variable names from name-space manager
3988  err_name = self._name_space_manager.create_name(
3989  root_name="ierr", context="PSyVars", label="ierr")
3990  kobj = self._name_space_manager.create_name(
3991  root_name="kernel_obj", context="ArgSetter", label="kernel_obj")
3992  parent.add(AssignGen(
3993  parent, lhs=err_name,
3994  rhs="clSetKernelArg({0}, {1}, C_SIZEOF({2}), C_LOC({2}))".
3995  format(kobj, index, self.name)))
3996  parent.add(CallGen(
3997  parent, "check_status",
3998  ["'clSetKernelArg: arg {0} of {1}'".format(index, kname),
3999  err_name]))
4000 
4001  def backward_dependence(self):
4002  '''Returns the preceding argument that this argument has a direct
4003  dependence with, or None if there is not one. The argument may
4004  exist in a call, a haloexchange, or a globalsum.
4005 
4006  :return: the first preceding argument this argument has a
4007  dependence with
4008  :rtype: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Argument`
4009 
4010  '''
4011  nodes = self._call.preceding(reverse=True)
4012  return self._find_argument(nodes)
4013 
4014  def backward_write_dependencies(self, ignore_halos=False):
4015  '''Returns a list of previous write arguments that this argument has
4016  dependencies with. The arguments may exist in a call, a
4017  haloexchange (unless `ignore_halos` is `True`), or a globalsum. If
4018  none are found then return an empty list. If self is not a
4019  reader then return an empty list.
4020 
4021  :param: ignore_halos: An optional, default `False`, boolean flag
4022  :type: ignore_halos: bool
4023  :return: a list of arguments that this argument has a dependence with
4024  :rtype: :func:`list` of :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Argument`
4025 
4026  '''
4027  nodes = self._call.preceding(reverse=True)
4028  results = self._find_write_arguments(nodes, ignore_halos=ignore_halos)
4029  return results
4030 
4031  def forward_dependence(self):
4032  '''Returns the following argument that this argument has a direct
4033  dependence with, or `None` if there is not one. The argument may
4034  exist in a call, a haloexchange, or a globalsum.
4035 
4036  :return: the first following argument this argument has a
4037  dependence with
4038  :rtype: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Argument`
4039 
4040  '''
4041  nodes = self._call.following()
4042  return self._find_argument(nodes)
4043 
4044  def forward_read_dependencies(self):
4045  '''Returns a list of following read arguments that this argument has
4046  dependencies with. The arguments may exist in a call, a
4047  haloexchange, or a globalsum. If none are found then
4048  return an empty list. If self is not a writer then return an
4049  empty list.
4050 
4051  :return: a list of arguments that this argument has a dependence with
4052  :rtype: :func:`list` of :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Argument`
4053 
4054  '''
4055  nodes = self._call.following()
4056  return self._find_read_arguments(nodes)
4057 
4058  def _find_argument(self, nodes):
4059  '''Return the first argument in the list of nodes that has a
4060  dependency with self. If one is not found return None
4061 
4062  :param: the list of nodes that this method examines
4063  :type: :func:`list` of :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Node`
4064  :return: An argument object or None
4065  :rtype: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Argument`
4066 
4067  '''
4068  nodes_with_args = [x for x in nodes if
4069  isinstance(x, (Call, HaloExchange, GlobalSum))]
4070  for node in nodes_with_args:
4071  for argument in node.args:
4072  if self._depends_on(argument):
4073  return argument
4074  return None
4075 
4076  def _find_read_arguments(self, nodes):
4077  '''Return a list of arguments from the list of nodes that have a read
4078  dependency with self. If none are found then return an empty
4079  list. If self is not a writer then return an empty list.
4080 
4081  :param: the list of nodes that this method examines
4082  :type: :func:`list` of :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Node`
4083  :return: a list of arguments that this argument has a dependence with
4084  :rtype: :func:`list` of :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Argument`
4085 
4086  '''
4087  if self.access not in self._write_access_types:
4088  # I am not a writer so there will be no read dependencies
4089  return []
4090 
4091  # We only need consider nodes that have arguments
4092  nodes_with_args = [x for x in nodes if
4093  isinstance(x, (Call, HaloExchange, GlobalSum))]
4094  access = DataAccess(self)
4095  arguments = []
4096  for node in nodes_with_args:
4097  for argument in node.args:
4098  # look at all arguments in our nodes
4099  if argument.access in self._read_access_types and \
4100  access.overlaps(argument):
4101  arguments.append(argument)
4102  if argument.access in self._write_access_types:
4103  access.update_coverage(argument)
4104  if access.covered:
4105  # We have now found all arguments upon which
4106  # this argument depends so return the list.
4107  return arguments
4108 
4109  # we did not find a terminating write dependence in the list
4110  # of nodes so we return any read dependencies that were found
4111  return arguments
4112 
4113  def _find_write_arguments(self, nodes, ignore_halos=False):
4114  '''Return a list of arguments from the list of nodes that have a write
4115  dependency with self. If none are found then return an empty
4116  list. If self is not a reader then return an empty list.
4117 
4118  :param: the list of nodes that this method examines
4119  :type: :func:`list` of :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Node`
4120  :param: ignore_halos: An optional, default `False`, boolean flag
4121  :type: ignore_halos: bool
4122  :return: a list of arguments that this argument has a dependence with
4123  :rtype: :func:`list` of :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Argument`
4124 
4125  '''
4126  if self.access not in self._read_access_types:
4127  # I am not a reader so there will be no write dependencies
4128  return []
4129 
4130  # We only need consider nodes that have arguments
4131  nodes_with_args = [x for x in nodes if
4132  isinstance(x, (Call, GlobalSum)) or
4133  (isinstance(x, HaloExchange) and not ignore_halos)]
4134  access = DataAccess(self)
4135  arguments = []
4136  for node in nodes_with_args:
4137  for argument in node.args:
4138  # look at all arguments in our nodes
4139  if argument.access not in self._write_access_types:
4140  # no dependence if not a writer
4141  continue
4142  if not access.overlaps(argument):
4143  # Accesses are independent of each other
4144  continue
4145  arguments.append(argument)
4146  access.update_coverage(argument)
4147  if access.covered:
4148  # sanity check
4149  if not isinstance(node, HaloExchange) and \
4150  len(arguments) > 1:
4151  raise InternalError(
4152  "Found a writer dependence but there are already "
4153  "dependencies. This should not happen.")
4154  # We have now found all arguments upon which this
4155  # argument depends so return the list.
4156  return arguments
4157  if arguments:
4158  raise InternalError(
4159  "Argument()._field_write_arguments() There are no more nodes "
4160  "but there are already dependencies. This should not happen.")
4161  # no dependencies have been found
4162  return []
4163 
4164  def _depends_on(self, argument):
4165  '''If there is a dependency between the argument and self then return
4166  True, otherwise return False. We consider there to be a
4167  dependency between two arguments if the names are the same and
4168  if one reads and one writes, or if both write. Dependencies
4169  are often defined as being read-after-write (RAW),
4170  write-after-read (WAR) and write after write (WAW). These
4171  dependencies can be considered to be forward dependencies, in
4172  the sense that RAW means that the read is after the write in
4173  the schedule. Similarly for WAR and WAW. We capture these
4174  dependencies in this method. However we also capture
4175  dependencies in the opposite direction (backward
4176  dependencies). These are the same dependencies as forward
4177  dependencies but are reversed. One could consider these to be
4178  read-before-write, write-before-read, and
4179  write-before-write. The terminology of forward and backward to
4180  indicate whether the argument we depend on is after or before
4181  us in the schedule is borrowed from loop dependence analysis
4182  where a forward dependence indicates a dependence in a future
4183  loop iteration and a backward dependence indicates a
4184  dependence on a previous loop iteration. Note, we currently
4185  assume that any read or write to an argument results in a
4186  dependence i.e. we do not consider the internal structure of
4187  the argument (e.g. it may be an array). However, this
4188  assumption is OK as all elements of an array are typically
4189  accessed. However, we may need to revisit this when we change
4190  the iteration spaces of loops e.g. for overlapping
4191  communication and computation.
4192 
4193  :param argument: the argument we will check to see whether
4194  there is a dependence with this argument instance (self)
4195  :type argument: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Argument`
4196  :return: True if there is a dependence and False if not
4197  :rtype: bool
4198 
4199  '''
4200  if argument.name == self._name:
4201  if self.access in self._write_access_types and \
4202  argument.access in self._read_access_types:
4203  return True
4204  if self.access in self._read_access_types and \
4205  argument.access in self._write_access_types:
4206  return True
4207  if self.access in self._write_access_types and \
4208  argument.access in self._write_access_types:
4209  return True
4210  return False
4211 
4212

4216  Argument.__init__(self, call, arg_info, arg.access)

4223  def stencil(self):
4224  return self._arg.stencil

4227 class TransInfo(object):
4228  '''
4229  This class provides information about, and access, to the available
4230  transformations in this implementation of PSyclone. New transformations
4231  will be picked up automatically as long as they subclass the abstract
4232  Transformation class.
4233 
4234  For example:
4235 
4236  >>> from psyclone.psyGen import TransInfo
4237  >>> t = TransInfo()
4238  >>> print(t.list)
4239  There is 1 transformation available:
4240  1: SwapTrans, A test transformation
4241  >>> # accessing a transformation by index
4242  >>> trans = t.get_trans_num(1)
4243  >>> # accessing a transformation by name
4244  >>> trans = t.get_trans_name("SwapTrans")
4245 
4246  '''
4247 
4248  def __init__(self, module=None, base_class=None):
4249  ''' if module and/or baseclass are provided then use these else use
4250  the default module "Transformations" and the default base_class
4251  "Transformation"'''
4252 
4253  if False:
4254  self._0_to_n = DummyTransformation() # only here for pyreverse!
4255 
4256  if module is None:
4257  # default to the transformation module
4258  from psyclone import transformations
4259  module = transformations
4260  if base_class is None:
4261  from psyclone import psyGen
4262  base_class = psyGen.Transformation
4263  # find our transformations
4264  self._classes = self._find_subclasses(module, base_class)
4265 
4266  # create our transformations
4267  self._objects = []
4268  self._obj_map = {}
4269  for my_class in self._classes:
4270  my_object = my_class()
4271  self._objects.append(my_object)
4272  self._obj_map[my_object.name] = my_object
4273 
4274  @property
4275  def list(self):
4276  ''' return a string with a human readable list of the available
4277  transformations '''
4278  import os
4279  if len(self._objects) == 1:
4280  result = "There is 1 transformation available:"
4281  else:
4282  result = "There are {0} transformations available:".format(
4283  len(self._objects))
4284  result += os.linesep
4285  for idx, my_object in enumerate(self._objects):
4286  result += " " + str(idx+1) + ": " + my_object.name + ": " + \
4287  str(my_object) + os.linesep
4288  return result
4289 
4290  @property
4291  def num_trans(self):
4292  ''' return the number of transformations available '''
4293  return len(self._objects)
4294 
4295  def get_trans_num(self, number):
4296  ''' return the transformation with this number (use list() first to
4297  see available transformations) '''
4298  if number < 1 or number > len(self._objects):
4299  raise GenerationError("Invalid transformation number supplied")
4300  return self._objects[number-1]
4301 
4302  def get_trans_name(self, name):
4303  ''' return the transformation with this name (use list() first to see
4304  available transformations) '''
4305  try:
4306  return self._obj_map[name]
4307  except KeyError:
4308  raise GenerationError("Invalid transformation name: got {0} "
4309  "but expected one of {1}".
4310  format(name, self._obj_map.keys()))
4311 
4312  def _find_subclasses(self, module, base_class):
4313  ''' return a list of classes defined within the specified module that
4314  are a subclass of the specified baseclass. '''
4315  import inspect
4316  return [cls for name, cls in inspect.getmembers(module)
4317  if inspect.isclass(cls) and not inspect.isabstract(cls) and
4318  issubclass(cls, base_class) and cls is not base_class]
4319

4430 class Fparser2ASTProcessor(object):
4431  '''
4432  Class to encapsulate the functionality for processing the fparser2 AST and
4433  convert the nodes to PSyIRe.

4435 
4436  def __init__(self):
4437  from fparser.two import Fortran2003, utils
4438  # Map of fparser2 node types to handlers (which are class methods)
4439  self.handlers = {
4440  Fortran2003.Assignment_Stmt: self._assignment_handler,
4441  Fortran2003.Name: self._name_handler,
4442  Fortran2003.Parenthesis: self._parenthesis_handler,
4443  Fortran2003.Part_Ref: self._part_ref_handler,
4444  Fortran2003.If_Stmt: self._if_stmt_handler,
4445  utils.NumberBase: self._number_handler,
4446  utils.BinaryOpBase: self._binary_op_handler,
4447  Fortran2003.End_Do_Stmt: self._ignore_handler,
4448  Fortran2003.End_Subroutine_Stmt: self._ignore_handler,
4449  # TODO: Issue #256, to cover all nemolite2D kernels we need:
4450  # Fortran2003.If_Construct: self._if_construct_handler,
4451  # Fortran2003.Return_Stmt: self._return_handler,
4452  # Fortran2003.UnaryOpBase: self._unaryOp_handler,
4453  # ... (some already partially implemented in nemo.py)
4454  }
4455 
4456  @staticmethod
4457  def nodes_to_code_block(parent, statements):
4458  '''
4459  Create a CodeBlock for the supplied list of statements
4460  and then wipe the list of statements. A CodeBlock is a node
4461  in the PSyIRe (Schedule) that represents a sequence of one or more
4462  Fortran statements which PSyclone does not attempt to handle.
4463 
4464  :param parent: Node in the PSyclone AST to which to add this code \
4465  block.
4466  :type parent: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Node`
4467  :param list statements: List of fparser2 AST nodes consituting the \
4468  code block.
4469  :rtype: :py:class:`psyclone.CodeBlock`
4470  '''
4471  if not statements:
4472  return None
4473 
4474  code_block = CodeBlock(statements, parent=parent)
4475  parent.addchild(code_block)
4476  del statements[:]
4477  return code_block
4478 
4479  # TODO remove nodes_parent argument once fparser2 AST contains
4480  # parent information (fparser/#102).
4481  def process_nodes(self, parent, nodes, nodes_parent):
4482  '''
4483  Create the PSyIRe of the supplied list of nodes in the
4484  fparser2 AST. Currently also inserts parent information back
4485  into the fparser2 AST. This is a workaround until fparser2
4486  itself generates and stores this information.
4487 
4488  :param parent: Parent node in the PSyIRe we are constructing.
4489  :type parent: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Node`
4490  :param nodes: List of sibling nodes in fparser2 AST.
4491  :type nodes: list of :py:class:`fparser.two.utils.Base`
4492  :param nodes_parent: the parent of the supplied list of nodes in \
4493  the fparser2 AST.
4494  :type nodes_parent: :py:class:`fparser.two.utils.Base`
4495  '''
4496  code_block_nodes = []
4497  for child in nodes:
4498  # TODO remove this line once fparser2 contains parent
4499  # information (fparser/#102)
4500  child._parent = nodes_parent # Retro-fit parent info
4501 
4502  try:
4503  psy_child = self._create_child(child, parent)
4504  except NotImplementedError:
4505  # If child type implementation not found, add them on the
4506  # ongoing code_block node list.
4507  code_block_nodes.append(child)
4508  else:
4509  if psy_child:
4510  self.nodes_to_code_block(parent, code_block_nodes)
4511  parent.addchild(psy_child)
4512  # If psy_child is not initialized but it didn't produce a
4513  # NotImplementedError, it means it is safe to ignore it.
4514 
4515  # Complete any unfinished code-block
4516  self.nodes_to_code_block(parent, code_block_nodes)
4517 
4518  def _create_child(self, child, parent=None):
4519  '''
4520  Create a PSyIRe node representing the supplied fparser 2 node.
4521 
4522  :param child: node in fparser2 AST.
4523  :type child: :py:class:`fparser.two.utils.Base`
4524  :param parent: Parent node of the PSyIRe node we are constructing.
4525  :type parent: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Node`
4526  :raises NotImplementedError: There isn't a handler for the provided \
4527  child type.
4528  :return: Returns the PSyIRe representation of child, which can be a
4529  single node, a tree of nodes or None if the child can be
4530  ignored.
4531  :rtype: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Node` or NoneType
4532  '''
4533  handler = self.handlers.get(type(child))
4534  if handler is None:
4535  # If the handler is not found then check with the first
4536  # level parent class. This is done to simplify the
4537  # handlers map when multiple fparser2 types can be
4538  # processed with the same handler. (e.g. Subclasses of
4539  # BinaryOpBase: Mult_Operand, Add_Operand, Level_2_Expr,
4540  # ... can use the same handler.)
4541  generic_type = type(child).__bases__[0]
4542  handler = self.handlers.get(generic_type)
4543  if not handler:
4544  raise NotImplementedError()
4545  return handler(child, parent)
4546 
4547  def _ignore_handler(self, node, parent): # pylint: disable=unused-argument
4548  '''
4549  This handler returns None indicating that the associated
4550  fparser2 node can be ignored.
4551 
4552  :param child: node in fparser2 AST.
4553  :type child: :py:class:`fparser.two.utils.Base`
4554  :param parent: Parent node of the PSyIRe node we are constructing.
4555  :type parent: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Node`
4556  :return: None
4557  :rtype: NoneType
4558  '''
4559  return None
4560 
4561  def _if_stmt_handler(self, node, parent):
4562  '''
4563  Transforms an fparser2 If_Stmt to the PSyIRe representation.
4564 
4565  :param child: node in fparser2 AST.
4566  :type child: :py:class:`fparser.two.Fortran2003.If_Stmt`
4567  :param parent: Parent node of the PSyIRe node we are constructing.
4568  :type parent: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Node`
4569  :return: PSyIRe representation of node
4570  :rtype: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.IfBlock`
4571  '''
4572  ifblock = IfBlock(parent=parent)
4573  self.process_nodes(parent=ifblock, nodes=[node.items[0]],
4574  nodes_parent=node)
4575  self.process_nodes(parent=ifblock, nodes=[node.items[1]],
4576  nodes_parent=node)
4577  return ifblock
4578 
4579  def _assignment_handler(self, node, parent):
4580  '''
4581  Transforms an fparser2 Assignment_Stmt to the PSyIRe representation.
4582 
4583  :param child: node in fparser2 AST.
4584  :type child: :py:class:`fparser.two.Fortran2003.Assignment_Stmt`
4585  :param parent: Parent node of the PSyIRe node we are constructing.
4586  :type parent: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Node`
4587  :return: PSyIRe representation of node
4588  :rtype: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Assignment`
4589  '''
4590  assignment = Assignment(parent=parent)
4591  self.process_nodes(parent=assignment, nodes=[node.items[0]],
4592  nodes_parent=node)
4593  self.process_nodes(parent=assignment, nodes=[node.items[2]],
4594  nodes_parent=node)
4595 
4596  return assignment
4597 
4598  def _binary_op_handler(self, node, parent):
4599  '''
4600  Transforms an fparser2 BinaryOp to the PSyIRe representation.
4601 
4602  :param child: node in fparser2 AST.
4603  :type child: :py:class:`fparser.two.utils.BinaryOpBase`
4604  :param parent: Parent node of the PSyIRe node we are constructing.
4605  :type parent: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Node`
4606  :return: PSyIRe representation of node
4607  :rtype: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.BinaryOperation`
4608  '''
4609  # Get the operator
4610  operator = node.items[1]
4611 
4612  binary_op = BinaryOperation(operator, parent=parent)
4613  self.process_nodes(parent=binary_op, nodes=[node.items[0]],
4614  nodes_parent=node)
4615  self.process_nodes(parent=binary_op, nodes=[node.items[2]],
4616  nodes_parent=node)
4617 
4618  return binary_op
4619

4622  Transforms an fparser2 Name to the PSyIRe representation.

4624  :param child: node in fparser2 AST.
4625  :type child: :py:class:`fparser.two.Fortran2003.Name`

4632 
4633  def _parenthesis_handler(self, node, parent):
4634  '''
4635  Transforms an fparser2 Parenthesis to the PSyIRe representation.
4636  This means ignoring the parentheis and process the fparser2 children
4637  inside.
4638 
4639  :param child: node in fparser2 AST.
4640  :type child: :py:class:`fparser.two.Fortran2003.Parenthesis`
4641  :param parent: Parent node of the PSyIRe node we are constructing.
4642  :type parent: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Node`
4643  :return: PSyIRe representation of node
4644  :rtype: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Node`
4645  '''
4646  # Use the items[1] content of the node as it contains the required
4647  # information (items[0] and items[2] just contain the left and right
4648  # brackets as strings so can be disregarded.
4649  return self._create_child(node.items[1], parent)
4650 
4651  def _part_ref_handler(self, node, parent):
4652  '''
4653  Transforms an fparser2 Part_Ref to the PSyIRe representation.
4654 
4655  :param child: node in fparser2 AST.
4656  :type child: :py:class:`fparser.two.Fortran2003.Part_Ref`
4657  :param parent: Parent node of the PSyIRe node we are constructing.
4658  :type parent: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Node`
4659  :return: PSyIRe representation of node
4660  :rtype: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Array`
4661  '''
4662  from fparser.two import Fortran2003
4663 
4664  reference_name = node.items[0].string
4665  array = Array(reference_name, parent)
4666 
4667  if isinstance(node.items[1], Fortran2003.Section_Subscript_List):
4668  subscript_list = node.items[1].items
4669 
4670  self.process_nodes(parent=array, nodes=subscript_list,
4671  nodes_parent=node.items[1])
4672  else:
4673  # When there is only one dimension fparser does not have
4674  # a Subscript_List
4675  self.process_nodes(parent=array, nodes=[node.items[1]],
4676  nodes_parent=node)
4677 
4678  return array

4694 class CodeBlock(Node):
4695  '''
4696  Node representing some generic Fortran code that PSyclone does not attempt
4697  to manipulate. As such it is a leaf in the PSyIRe and therefore has no
4698  children.
4699 
4700  :param statements: list of fparser2 AST nodes representing the Fortran \
4701  code constituting the code block.
4702  :type statements: list of :py:class:`fparser.two.utils.Base`
4703  :param parent: the parent node of this code block in the PSyIRe.
4704  :type parent: :py:class:`psyclone.psyGen.Node`
4705  '''
4706  def __init__(self, statements, parent=None):
4707  super(CodeBlock, self).__init__(parent=parent)
4708  # Store a list of the parser objects holding the code associated
4709  # with this block. We make a copy of the contents of the list because
4710  # the list itself is a temporary product of the process of converting
4711  # from the fparser2 AST to the PSyIRe.
4712  self._statements = statements[:]
4713 
4714  @property
4715  def coloured_text(self):
4716  '''
4717  Return the name of this node type with control codes for
4718  terminal colouring.
4719 
4720  :return: Name of node + control chars for colour.
4721  :rtype: str
4722  '''
4723  return colored("CodeBlock", SCHEDULE_COLOUR_MAP["CodeBlock"])
4724 
4725  def view(self, indent=0):
4726  '''
4727  Print a representation of this node in the schedule to stdout.
4728 
4729  :param int indent: level to which to indent output.
4730  '''
4731  print(self.indent(indent) + self.coloured_text + "[" +
4732  str(list(map(type, self._statements))) + "]")
4733 
4734  def __str__(self):
4735  return "CodeBlock[{0} statements]".format(len(self._statements))
